from supabase import create_client

SUPABASE_URL = ''https://kshrhufpoltrbgzuagyb.supabase.co''
SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY = ''eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJpc3MiOiJzdXBhYmFzZSIsInJlZiI6ImtzaHJodWZwb2x0cmJnenVhZ3liIiwicm9sZSI6InNlcnZpY2Vfcm9sZSIsImlhdCI6MTc2NTcwODA2MCwiZXhwIjoyMDgxMjg0MDYwfQ.XmiaE1VClRsh6xsV39iqCfk3PaikmpN3oSm0FXc8aXo''

supabase = create_client(SUPABASE_URL, SUPABASE_SERVICE_KEY)

# Find user by email
users = supabase.auth.admin.list_users()
user = next((u for u in users if u.email == ''shaitamam@gmail.com''), None)

if user:
    print(f''Found user: {user.id}'')
    # Update tier to admin
    result = supabase.table(''profiles'').update({''tier'': ''admin''}).eq(''id'', user.id).execute()
    print(f''Updated profile to admin: {result.data}'')
else:
    print(''User not found'')
")

Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Add complete Find My Journal SaaS application

Features:
- FastAPI backend with OpenAlex journal search integration
- React + Vite + Tailwind CSS frontend
- Supabase authentication with JWT tokens
- Role-based access control (free/paid/admin tiers)
- Rate limiting for free users (5 searches/day)
- Hybrid search algorithm with discipline detection
- Specialized journal filtering by topic relevance
- E2E tests with Playwright

Backend:
- OpenAlex API integration for journal discovery
- Works-based and source-based hybrid search strategy
- Discipline-specific filtering to improve relevance
- Supabase integration for auth and search logging

Frontend:
- Login/SignUp pages with Supabase Auth
- Protected search page with form validation
- Journal results with metrics display
- Search limit indicator in header

Bash("C:\Users\shait\Documents\-Find-My-Journal-\venv\Scripts\python.exe" -c "
import asyncio
from app.services.openalex_service import OpenAlexService

async def test():
    service = OpenAlexService()
    results = await service.search_journals_by_text(
        title=''Exploring the Roots of Kindness: Validating the Social-Emotional Responding Task (SERT) for Infants and Toddlers'',
        abstract=''A total of 179 caregivers in Leipzig, Germany completed the adapted SERT, as well as measures for the purpose of validating the adapted SERT, including social-emotional and behavioral problems (BITSEA; Briggs-Gowan & Carter 2007), temperament (IBQ/ECBQ; Putnam et al., 2013, 2006), and conscience development (Kochanska et al., 1994). Internal consistency was found across all empathy for others, empathy for the self, and emotion regulation precursor constructs (Î± =.75â€“.87). Confirmatory factor analyses showed good convergence and fit for each construct (CFI=.91-.99; TLI=.90-.99; RMSEA=.03-.08; SRMR =.04-.07). Structural equation modeling provided some initial support for construct validity: empathy for others and self (Î² = .26, .20, p = .016, .047, respectively) were associated with higher competence scores, reflecting early social-emotional, communicative, and regulatory abilities.'',
        keywords=[''kindness'', ''empathy'', ''toddlerhood'', ''infancy'', ''social-emotional development''],
        discipline=''psychology''
    )
    print(f''Total found: {results.total_found}'')
    print(f''Discipline: {results.detected_discipline}'')
    for j in results.journals[:10]:
        print(f''  - {j.name} (score: {j.relevance_score:.2f}, reason: {j.match_reason})'')

asyncio.run(test())
")

import asyncio
from app.services.openalex_service import OpenAlexService

async def test():
    service = OpenAlexService()
    results = await service.search_journals_by_text(
        title=''Exploring the Roots of Kindness: Validating the Social-Emotional Responding Task (SERT) for Infants and Toddlers'',
        abstract=''A total of 179 caregivers in Leipzig, Germany completed the adapted SERT, as well as measures for the purpose of validating the adapted SERT, including social-emotional and behavioral problems (BITSEA; Briggs-Gowan & Carter 2007), temperament (IBQ/ECBQ; Putnam et al., 2013, 2006), and conscience development (Kochanska et al., 1994). Internal consistency was found across all empathy for others, empathy for the self, and emotion regulation precursor constructs. Confirmatory factor analyses showed good convergence and fit for each construct. Structural equation modeling provided some initial support for construct validity.'',
        keywords=[''kindness'', ''empathy'', ''toddlerhood'', ''infancy'', ''social-emotional development'']
    )
    print(f''Total found: {results.total_found}'')
    print(f''Discipline: {results.detected_discipline}'')

asyncio.run(test())
")

Bash("C:\Users\shait\Documents\-Find-My-Journal-\venv\Scripts\python.exe" -c "
import requests
import json

response = requests.post(
    ''http://localhost:8000/api/v1/search'',
    json={
        ''title'': ''Exploring the Roots of Kindness'',
        ''abstract'': ''A total of 179 caregivers in Leipzig completed the adapted SERT including social-emotional measures'',
        ''keywords'': [''kindness'', ''empathy'', ''toddlerhood'']
    },
    timeout=60
)
print(f''Status: {response.status_code}'')
data = response.json()
print(f''Total found: {data.get(""total_found"", ""N/A"")}'')
print(f''Discipline: {data.get(""detected_discipline"", ""N/A"")}'')
journals = data.get(''journals'', [])
for j in journals[:10]:
    print(f''  - {j[""name""]} (score: {j.get(""relevance_score"", 0):.2f})'')
")

Bash("C:\Users\shait\Documents\-Find-My-Journal-\venv\Scripts\python.exe" -c "
from app.services.openalex_service import OpenAlexService

service = OpenAlexService()
journals, discipline = service.search_journals_by_text(
    title=''Exploring the Roots of Kindness: Validating the Social-Emotional Responding Task (SERT) for Infants and Toddlers'',
    abstract=''A total of 179 caregivers in Leipzig, Germany completed the adapted SERT, as well as measures for the purpose of validating the adapted SERT, including social-emotional and behavioral problems (BITSEA; Briggs-Gowan & Carter 2007), temperament (IBQ/ECBQ; Putnam et al., 2013, 2006), and conscience development (Kochanska et al., 1994). Internal consistency was found across all empathy for others, empathy for the self, and emotion regulation precursor constructs. Confirmatory factor analyses showed good convergence and fit for each construct. Structural equation modeling provided some initial support for construct validity.'',
    keywords=[''kindness'', ''empathy'', ''toddlerhood'', ''infancy'', ''social-emotional development'']
)
print(f''Total found: {len(journals)}'')
print(f''Discipline: {discipline}'')
for j in journals[:15]:
    print(f''  - {j.name} | category: {j.category} | score: {j.relevance_score:.2f}'')
")

Bash("../venv/Scripts/python.exe" -c "
import asyncio
from app.models.journal import Journal, JournalMetrics
from app.services.trust_safety import verify_journal

# Create a mock journal that matches a blacklisted name
blacklisted_journal = Journal(
    id=''test1'',
    name=''Academic Exchange Quarterly'',
    publisher=''Test Publisher'',
    issn=''0000-0000'',
    topics=[],
    metrics=JournalMetrics(),
    is_oa=False,
    is_in_doaj=False,
)

# Create a legitimate mock journal
good_journal = Journal(
    id=''test2'',
    name=''Nature'',
    publisher=''Springer Nature'',
    issn=''0028-0836'',
    topics=[''Biology'', ''Physics''],
    metrics=JournalMetrics(h_index=500, works_count=100000),
    is_oa=False,
    is_in_doaj=False,
)

# Create a DOAJ-verified journal
doaj_journal = Journal(
    id=''test3'',
    name=''PLOS ONE'',
    publisher=''PLOS'',
    issn=''1932-6203'',
    topics=[''Biology''],
    metrics=JournalMetrics(h_index=300, works_count=500000),
    is_oa=True,
    is_in_doaj=True,
)

async def test():
    print(''Testing verification flow...'')
    print(''='' * 60)
    
    # Test blacklisted journal
    result1 = await verify_journal(blacklisted_journal)
    print(f''1. {result1.name}'')
    print(f''   Badge: {result1.verification.badge_color}'')
    print(f''   Status: {result1.verification.status_text}'')
    print(f''   Reasons: {result1.verification.reasons}'')
    print()
    
    # Test good journal (no specific verification)
    result2 = await verify_journal(good_journal)
    print(f''2. {result2.name}'')
    print(f''   Badge: {result2.verification.badge_color}'')
    print(f''   Status: {result2.verification.status_text}'')
    print()
    
    # Test DOAJ journal
    result3 = await verify_journal(doaj_journal)
    print(f''3. {result3.name}'')
    print(f''   Badge: {result3.verification.badge_color}'')
    print(f''   Status: {result3.verification.status_text}'')
    if result3.verification.verified_by:
        print(f''   Verified by: {result3.verification.verified_by}'')
    print(''='' * 60)

asyncio.run(test())
")

Bash("../venv/Scripts/python.exe" -c "
import asyncio
from app.models.journal import Journal, JournalMetrics
from app.services.trust_safety import verify_journal

# Create Nature with proper metrics (high citations)
nature_journal = Journal(
    id=''test2'',
    name=''Nature'',
    publisher=''Springer Nature'',
    issn=''0028-0836'',
    topics=[''Biology'', ''Physics''],
    metrics=JournalMetrics(
        h_index=500,
        works_count=100000,
        cited_by_count=50000000,  # 50 million citations
    ),
    is_oa=False,
    is_in_doaj=False,
)

# Small journal with no verification (should be GRAY)
small_journal = Journal(
    id=''test3'',
    name=''Unknown Small Journal'',
    publisher=''Some Publisher'',
    issn=None,
    topics=[],
    metrics=JournalMetrics(works_count=100),  # Below threshold for heuristics
    is_oa=False,
    is_in_doaj=False,
)

async def test():
    print(''Testing verification flow with proper data...'')
    print(''='' * 60)

    # Test Nature with proper citations
    result1 = await verify_journal(nature_journal)
    print(f''1. {result1.name}'')
    print(f''   Badge: {result1.verification.badge_color}'')
    print(f''   Status: {result1.verification.status_text}'')
    if result1.verification.reasons:
        print(f''   Reasons: {result1.verification.reasons}'')
    print()

    # Test small unknown journal
    result2 = await verify_journal(small_journal)
    print(f''2. {result2.name}'')
    print(f''   Badge: {result2.verification.badge_color}'')
    print(f''   Status: {result2.verification.status_text}'')
    if result2.verification.reasons:
        print(f''   Reasons: {result2.verification.reasons}'')

    print(''='' * 60)

asyncio.run(test())
")
